mental_model.explanation: Standard hooks are like generic brown boxes in a warehouse. `useDebugValue` lets you slap a custom label on the box (like 'Fragile' or 'Contents: 5 items') so when you inspect the warehouse (DevTools), you know exactly what's inside without opening it.

real_world_use_cases: Developing a shared library of custom hooks (e.g., react-query, use-hooks).
displaying the current status of a complex hook (e.g., 'Connected', 'Loading', 'Error') in DevTools.
Formatting a date or large object into a human-readable string for debugging purposes.

related_concepts.relationship: The only place where useDebugValue is actually useful.
The tool where the output of useDebugValue is displayed.

concepts.name: Definition
concepts.description: useDebugValue is a React Hook that lets you display a label for custom hooks in React DevTools.
details: It is designed for developers building libraries or complex custom hooks.
It does nothing for the end-user application; it only affects the developer experience in DevTools.
You should not add it to every custom hook, only those that are reused and complex.

code_example.explanation: In React DevTools, instead of just seeing 'State: true', you will see 'OnlineStatus: "Online"', making it instantly clear what the hook is doing.

concepts.name: Deferred Formatting
concepts.description: Formatting a debug value might be expensive (e.g., parsing dates). useDebugValue supports a second argument to defer this work.
details: Pass a formatting function as the second argument.
React will only call this function if the Hooks are actually inspected in DevTools.
This prevents performance penalties in production or when DevTools is closed.

code_example.explanation: The `toDateString()` method is only called when you click on this hook in DevTools.
